article_title: Sculley takes her message directly to rank-and-file cops
article_text:
Sculley takes her message directly to rank-and-file cops

Photo: John Davenport /San Antonio Express-News City Manager Sheryl Sculley (left), joined Mayor Ivy Taylor...

Over the course of more than a year of contentious collective bargaining with San Antonio’s police union, City Manager Sheryl Sculley has taken her case to council members, local media, union leadership and titans of the business community.

article_metadata.description: Over the course of more than a year of contentious collective bargaining with San Antonio’s police union, City Manager Sheryl Sculley has taken her case to council members, local media, union leadership and titans of the business community.  Sculley circumvented the San Antonio Police Officers Association (SAPOA) by sending an email to local cops with the following subject line: “Update on the Status of Collective Bargaining.”  Sculley went on to lay out the details of the city’s most recent proposal, which she described as “consistent with our goal of negotiating collective bargaining agreements that are fair to our employees and affordable to the taxpayers.”  According to one attendee, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, Sculley said City Attorney Martha Sepeda discouraged her from sending it.,  In a statement provided to the Express-News, Sculley explained her objective this way: I wrote to the employees to thank and recognize the officers for their hard work in achieving improved response times, lower crime rates and reductions in complaints.  The communication also updated officers on the status of police officer vacancies, future academy classes and an update on the city’s March proposal to the labor union.
article_metadata.author.name: By Gilbert Garcia, Metro Columnist
